choices.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is the usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inadequate patient preparation

 

Inadequate preparation of a patient with hyperthyroidism before thyroidectomy, such as not optimizing thyroid function and medication management, can increase the risk of thyroid storm. Proper preoperative management and stabilization of thyroid function are crucial to prevent this complication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rough handling of thyroid during surgery: While rough handling during thyroid surgery can potentially lead to complications, it is not the usual cause of thyroid storm.

 

Option B. Due to parathyroid gland injury: The parathyroid glands are separate from the thyroid gland and regulate calcium levels in the body. Complications involving the parathyroid glands can occur during thyroid surgery leading to postoperative hypocalcemia.

 

Option D. Infections: Infections can occur as complications after thyroid surgery, but they are not the usual cause of thyroid storm. Thyroid storm is primarily related to the excessive release of thyroid hormones into the bloodstream.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A thyroid storm, also known as thyrotoxic crisis, is a rare but life-threatening medical emergency that occurs in individuals with severe hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland produces an excessive amount of thyroid hormones, primarily thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). In a thyroid storm, these hormone levels become dangerously elevated, leading to a wide range of symptoms and complications.

 

Symptoms of a thyroid storm may include:

 

  1. High fever
  2. Rapid and irregular heartbeat (tachycardia)
  3. Elevated blood pressure
  4. Extreme agitation and restlessness
  5. Profuse sweating
  6. Tremors and shaking
  7. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
  8. Delirium or confusion
  9. Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
  10. Coma (in severe cases)

 

Thyroid storms can be triggered by various factors, such as surgery, infection, trauma, or medication changes in individuals with underlying hyperthyroidism. The condition is more common in people with Graves' disease, a common cause of hyperthyroidism.

 

Treatment of a thyroid storm is a medical emergency and typically involves a combination of interventions to rapidly lower thyroid hormone levels, control symptoms, and support vital organ function.

 

The usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is inadequate patient preparation before surgery. Thus, patient preparation pre-operatively involves ensuring a euthyroid state.

questions.text: The image below shows strangulation by Spanish windlass method. What type of strangulation method does it belong to? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Garroting

 

Spanish windlass

 

Method: It involves tightening an iron collar (Spanish windlass) around the neck and forcing a spike against the neck into the spinal cord.

 

Garroting- It involves attacking the victim by throwing the ligature from behind over the victim's neck and then tightened by twisting with a lever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bansdola: A method of strangulation where a ligature is applied in a different manner, often using a stick or rod to twist and tighten the ligature.

 

Option C. Mugging: Refers to a method where the assailant uses their limbs, such as the crook of their elbow, to compress the neck.

 

Option D. Throttling: Throttling involves using hands to manually compress the neck, leading to asphyxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Spanish windlass method of strangulation, shown in the image, belongs to the category of garroting, which involves the use of a ligature tightened by a lever or similar mechanism.

choices.text: Efficacy of drug A is more than that of drug B.
﻿﻿﻿Potency of drug B is more than that of drug A.
﻿﻿﻿Drug A and drug B are agonists.
﻿﻿﻿Drug C is a non-competitive antagonist.

questions.text: The dose-response curve for three drugs in the same tissue is shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Drug A and drug B are agonists.

 

  • From the given image, it can be understood that the Drug A and Drug B are agonists, i.e., they will bind to the receptor and produce the action after activating it.
  • The drug A is more potent than drug B but the efficacy of both the drugs are the same.
  • The Drug C also produces the action after binding to the receptor, but the degree of the response is less than that of Drugs A and B, or in other words its intrinsic efficacy is not equal to that of drugs A and B. Hence it is a partial agonist. In the presence of full agonists, the partial agonist behaves as an antagonist.
  • Drug C can be a competitive irreversible antagonist (not non-competitive) as the curve is shifting to right and down.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement A: Efficacy of drug A is more than that of drug B: This statement is false. The efficacy of a drug is determined by the maximum response it can produce. From the graph, both Drug A and Drug B achieve the same maximum response, indicating that their efficacies are the same.

 

Statement B: Potency of drug B is more than that of drug A: This statement is false. Potency is determined by the position of the dose-response curve along the concentration axis. The lower the ED50 (the concentration required to achieve 50% of the maximum response), the more potent the drug. From the graph, Drug A reaches its ED50 at a lower concentration than Drug B, indicating that Drug A is more potent than Drug B.

 

Statement D: Drug C is a non-competitive antagonist: This statement is false. Drug C achieves only a partial response compared to Drugs A and B, indicating that Drug C is a partial agonist, not a non-competitive antagonist. Non-competitive antagonists would typically reduce the efficacy of an agonist without affecting the potency in such a dose-response curve. The curve for Drug C does not align with the expected behavior of a non-competitive antagonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key Points:

 

  1. Agonists: Drugs A and B are full agonists because they can achieve the maximum response.
  2. Partial Agonist: Drug C produces a submaximal response compared to Drugs A and B, which indicates it is a partial agonist.
  3. Potency: Drug A is more potent than Drug B because it achieves 50% of its maximum response at a lower concentration.
  4. Non-competitive Antagonist: Drug C is not a non-competitive antagonist, as it does not simply reduce the efficacy of another agonist but instead acts as a partial agonist on its own.

questions.text: Breast cancer of size 6 x 8 cm with dimpling with invasion of Pectoralis Major and ipsilateral matted axillary nodes belongs to what TNM stage? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T3N2M0

 

  • Tumor size > 5 cm = T3
  • Skin dimpling does not affect T stage (common misconception)
  • Invasion of pectoralis major does not affect T stage
  • Only skin ulceration, peau d'orange, or satellite nodules make it T4b
  • Ipsilateral matted axillary nodes = N2
  • No mention of distant metastasis = M0


Other Options: 

 

Option B. T4bN1M0:

 

  • Skin dimpling alone does not make it T4b
  • N1 represents mobile nodes, while the question mentions matted nodes (N2)
     

Option C. T4aN2M0:

 

  • T4a represents chest wall invasion (not including pectoralis major)
  • Invasion of pectoralis major alone does not make it T4a
     

Option D. T2N2M1:

 

  • T2 is for tumors 2-5 cm, this tumor is > 5 cm

  • No evidence of distant metastasis (M1)

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skin dimpling and pectoralis major invasion do not affect T stage in breast cancer TNM staging
  • T3 stage is for tumors > 5 cm
  • Matted axillary nodes represent N2 disease

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought with the complaints of protrusion of the right eye with no h/o fever. CT Scan showed a well-defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which were positive for Desmin in Immunohistochemistry. What is the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rhabdomyosarcoma  

 

Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical and histological findings. It is a malignant tumor derived from skeletal muscle and commonly presents in the pediatric population as a rapidly enlarging orbital mass, often causing displacement of the eye (proptosis). The biopsy findings of small, round cells positive for Desmin, a muscle-specific intermediate filament, support the diagnosis. The location and aggressive nature of the tumor, indicated by bony destruction, are characteristic of rhabdomyosarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: This is a common malignant intraocular tumor of childhood but would not typically present with bony destruction or be positive for Desmin.

 

Option B. Cavernous Hemangioma: This is a benign vascular tumor seen in adults and is not associated with rapid progression or positive Desmin staining.

 

Option C. Orbital Cellulitis: This infection would present with signs of inflammation and fever, which are not described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Increase the dose
Decrease the dose
Stop the drug
Stop retigabine and start on carbamazepine

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with epilepsy was put on retigabine thrice a day. Now phenytoin is being added. Which of the following changes should be made to retigabine therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Increase the dose

 

In the scenario where phenytoin is added to a patient's epilepsy treatment regimen that already includes retigabine, and if one of the provided options must be chosen, the most appropriate choice, based on known pharmacological interactions, would be:

 

  • The rationale for this choice is based on the enzyme-inducing properties of phenytoin. Phenytoin is known to induce hepatic enzymes that metabolize many drugs, potentially leading to reduced levels of these drugs. The general principle of enzyme induction suggests that the levels of retigabine could be decreased when phenytoin is added. Therefore, an increase in the dose of retigabine may be necessary to maintain therapeutic drug levels and effective seizure control.
  • However, it's important to emphasize that any dose adjustment should be made cautiously and based on clinical monitoring, including assessing the efficacy of seizure control and watching for any potential side effects. The decision should be individualized and ideally supported by drug level monitoring if available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease the dose: Decreasing the dose of retigabine would be counterproductive, as the enzyme-inducing effect of phenytoin would lower the drug levels, requiring an increase rather than a decrease.

 

Option C. Stop the drug: Stopping retigabine is not advisable without a clear indication of severe side effects or failure to control seizures. Retigabine can be an effective antiepileptic, and its discontinuation should be based on clinical judgment and not just due to the addition of another drug.

 

Option D. Stop retigabine and start on carbamazepine: This option suggests switching to another antiepileptic drug. While carbamazepine is another enzyme inducer like phenytoin, switching medications is not necessary unless there are specific reasons to do so, such as intolerability or ineffectiveness of retigabine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When phenytoin, an enzyme inducer, is added to a regimen that includes retigabine, the dose of retigabine should be increased to compensate for the increased metabolism and maintain effective seizure control.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubulin

 

Tubulin is a part of microtubules and is not an intermediate filament.

 

The intermediate filaments comprise the major component of the cytoskeleton and consist of five major subgroups—vimentin, keratins, desmin, neurofilaments, and glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)—and a small number of minor subgroups (e.g., nestin, peripherin).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vimentin: Vimentin is an intermediate filament protein commonly found in cells of mesenchymal origin. It helps maintain cellular integrity and provides resistance to stress.

 

Option C. Desmin: Desmin is an intermediate filament protein found predominantly in muscle cells. It is crucial for maintaining the structural integrity of muscle cells by linking the cytoskeletal network to the sarcomere.

 

Option D. Neurofilament: Neurofilaments are intermediate filaments found in neurons. They are important for maintaining the shape and strength of nerve cells and play a role in the conduction of nerve impulses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubulin is not an intermediate filament; it is a protein that forms microtubules, which are essential for cell shape, motility, and division. Intermediate filaments, such as vimentin, desmin, and neurofilaments, provide mechanical support and structural integrity to cells.

questions.text:
Chronic HBV infection would be consistent with which of the following serology? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. HBsAg
  2. Anti-HBsAg
  3. Anti-HBcAg
  4. HBV DNA
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4

 

Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): This antibody appears after the infection has been cleared or following successful vaccination. It indicates immunity to HBV. In chronic HBV infection, this antibody is not present since the surface antigen is still active.

 

Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is defined by the persistence of the surface antigen (HBsAg) for more than six months. The presence of HBsAg indicates an active HBV infection.

 

Serological markers:

 

1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This antigen indicates that the person is infectious. It is found in the blood during acute and chronic HBV infection. The presence of HBsAg for more than six months defines chronic HBV infection.

 

3. Anti-HBc (Hepatitis B core antibody): This antibody indicates previous or ongoing infection with HBV. In chronic infection, the IgG fraction of anti-HBc is usually present.

 

4. HBV DNA: The presence of HBV DNA in the blood indicates active viral replication. It is usually detectable in chronic HBV infection, although the levels can vary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic HBV infection is characterized by the persistence of HBsAg, the presence of Anti-HBc, and usually detectable HBV DNA. Anti-HBs is not present in chronic HBV infection as it indicates immunity.

questions.text:
Match the following: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1 - Kleptomania
2 - Pyromania
3 - Mutilomania
4 - Dipsomania

 

A - Intense desire to drink alcoholic drinks
B - Intense desire to mutilate
C - Intense desire to steal items of trivial value
D - Intense desire to burn things
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

The correct option is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

 

Impulse control disorders are characterized by the repeated failure to resist an impulse, drive, or urge to perform an act that is rewarding to the person, at least in the short term, despite the long-term harm either to the individual or to others. These disorders involve marked distress about the behavior pattern or impairment in personal, family, social, educational, or other important areas of functioning.

 

These disorders include:

 

  1. Pyromania: The deliberate setting of fires on more than one occasion.
  2. Kleptomania: The recurrent inability to resist urges to steal objects that are of little or no personal use.
  3. Compulsive sexual behavior disorder (not directly in this question but part of impulse control disorders).
  4. Intermittent explosive disorder: Repeated episodes of impulsive, aggressive, violent behavior.

 

Kleptomania is the repeated failure to resist impulses to steal objects of trivial value, and the act is not driven by personal need. The stolen items are typically returned, given away, or kept hidden.

 

Pyromania involves the intentional setting of fires, and is associated with disorders like substance abuse, depression, and personality disturbances.

 

Dipsomania refers to an irresistible impulse to consume alcoholic beverages at periodic intervals.

 

Mutilomania is the irresistible urge to mutilate animals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Impulse control disorders include kleptomania (urge to steal), pyromania (urge to set fires), dipsomania (urge to drink alcohol), and mutilomania (urge to mutilate). These behaviors are driven by compulsions and often result in distress or impairment despite their immediate rewarding nature.

questions.text: Match the malignancies with the responsible genes: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Pleomorphic adenoma: This benign salivary gland tumor is associated with the overexpression of the Plag-1 proto-oncogene. Plag-1 plays a significant role in the tumorigenesis of pleomorphic adenoma, making option d the correct match.
  2. Burkitt's lymphoma: This aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma is most commonly associated with the translocation of the C-myc gene, particularly t(8;14) or t(8;22). This translocation leads to the overexpression of the C-myc oncogene, driving the proliferation of lymphoid cells, making option c the correct match.
  3. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood and is associated with amplification of the N-myc gene. N-myc plays a critical role in the aggressive behavior of neuroblastoma, making option b the correct match.
  4. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma, the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children, is associated with mutations in the Rb gene. The Rb gene is a tumor suppressor that regulates cell cycle progression, and its inactivation leads to uncontrolled cell division, making option a the correct match.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following pathological bodies with their associated condition: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

The correct pairing of pathological bodies with their associated conditions is:

 

  • Parkinson's Disease - Lewy body (A-3): Lewy bodies are intracellular inclusions found in neurons of substantia nigra in Parkinson's disease
  • Rabies - Negri body (B-2): Negri bodies are pathognomonic intracytoplasmic inclusions found in neurons infected with rabies virus
  • Multiple myeloma - Dutcher body (C-1): Dutcher bodies are intranuclear inclusions found in plasma cells in multiple myeloma
  • Malakoplakia - Michaelis-Gutmann body (D-4): These are pathognomonic intracellular calcified bodies found in macrophages in malakoplakia

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Lewy bodies → Parkinson's disease

 

 

  • Negri bodies → Rabies

 

 

  • Dutcher bodies → Multiple myeloma

 

 

  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies → Malakoplakia

questions.text: What is an infrequent yet highly serious adverse outcome of clozapine that necessitates consistent monitoring?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Agranulocytosis

 

CLOZAPINE

 

  • Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS)- Lack of response to at least two different antipsychotics, including at least one second-generation antipsychotic, given in adequate dosage and for an adequate duration (at least 4-6 weeks).
  • Clozapine is the drug of choice (DOC) in TRS.
  • Unique mechanism of action- More affinity for D4 than D2, hence causes minimal EPS.
  • Antipsychotic that causes max weight gain.
  • Clozapine is the only antipsychotic with antisuicide property.

 

Side effects of clozapine

 

  • Life-threatening: Agranulocytosis (idiosyncratic), myocarditis (idiosyncratic), seizures (dose-dependent)
  • Sedation (most common), sialorrhea
  • Syncope, hypotension, tachycardia, nausea, vomiting
  • Weight gain, anticholinergic side effects
  • Due to the possibility of agranulocytosis, when a patient is on clozapine, ANC and TLC monitoring is required.
  • The regime of monitoring-
    • First 6 months- Once a week
    • Next 6 months- Once in two weeks
    • After 1 year- Once in four weeks, till clozapine is continued 
  • Stop clozapine, if WBC < 3000/dl or ANC < 1500/dl
  • Contraindications for clozapine use
    • WBC < 3500/dl
    • History of agranulocytosis on clozapine
    • Use of other bone marrow suppressants like carbamazepine

choices.text: Protects the acid labile drug from gastric acidity
Protects the gastric mucosa from irritant effects of certain drugs
Prolongs the half-life of the drug

questions.text: Many drugs are given as enteric coated tablets. All of the following are the advantages of enteric coating of drugs EXCEPT? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prolongs the half-life of the drug

 

Enteric coatings on tablets protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity, protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects, and deliver drugs distal to the stomach. However, they do not prolong the half-life of a drug, which is determined by the drug's metabolism and elimination from the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Enteric-coated drugs are designed with a special coating that resists dissolution in the acidic environment of the stomach. This coating dissolves instead in the more alkaline environment of the small intestine. The primary purposes of this enteric coating are:

 

Option A. Protect the acid-labile drug from gastric acidity: Some drugs are unstable in the acidic environment of the stomach and can be degraded before they have a chance to be absorbed. Enteric coating protects these drugs from the acidic gastric environment, ensuring they reach the intestine, where they can be absorbed effectively.

 

Option B. Protect the gastric mucosa from the irritant effects of certain drugs: Certain drugs can irritate the gastric mucosa, leading to discomfort or even ulcers. Enteric coating prevents these drugs from being released in the stomach, thereby reducing the risk of gastric irritation.

 

Option D. Deliver drugs distal to the stomach: Enteric coating is also used to ensure that a drug is released in the intestine rather than the stomach, which can be important for drugs that are intended to act in the intestine or are better absorbed from the intestinal lining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enteric coating is primarily used to protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity, protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects, and ensure drug delivery distal to the stomach. It does not prolong the half-life of the drug.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is not performed via the perineal approach in a patient with rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein operation

 

This procedure is designed to treat rectal prolapse. It involves fixing the rectum to the sacrum using a synthetic mesh. This procedure is performed via an abdominal approach and not through the perineum. Hence, the answer to the question is A) Ripstein operation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiersch operation: The Thiersch operation is a perineal procedure. It involves placing a wire or other synthetic material around the anus to encircle and narrow it. This provides support to the anal canal and rectum, helping to prevent or treat rectal prolapse.

 

Option C. Altemeier procedure: Also known as the perineal rectal resection, the Altemeier procedure is a surgical treatment for rectal prolapse. During this operation, the prolapsed portion of the rectum is resected, and the remaining rectum is sutured back to the anal canal. This procedure is performed through the perineal approach.

 

Option D. Delorme operation: The Delorme operation is a perineal approach to treat rectal prolapse. The mucosa and submucosa of the prolapsed rectum are excised, and the muscularis is plicated. The remaining mucosa is then sutured back. This procedure is typically reserved for older patients or those who are not candidates for a more invasive abdominal procedure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with left facial weakness. Routine lab workup was normal. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corticosteroids

 

The presentation of left facial weakness with normal routine lab workup suggests Bell's palsy, an idiopathic condition characterized by sudden onset of unilateral lower motor neuron facial paralysis. Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion and is the most common cause of unilateral facial paralysis.

 

Corticosteroids: The first-line treatment for Bell's palsy is corticosteroids. They are most effective when started within 72 hours of symptom onset. Early treatment with corticosteroids can significantly improve the chances of complete recovery. A typical regimen is prednisolone or prednisone.

 

Dosage: Prednisone 60-80 mg per day for 5-7 days, followed by a taper over the next 5-7 days.

 

Note – In the severity grading system, House-Brackmann grading, if the patient has Grade 4 or Grade 5 severity, consider adding antivirals such as acyclovir or valacyclovir.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir: Although acyclovir or other antiviral agents like valacyclovir are sometimes used, their benefit is less clear. They may be considered in severe cases of Bell's palsy, particularly when there is a suspicion of herpes simplex virus involvement, but they are not the primary treatment.

 

Dosage: Valacyclovir 1 gram TID for 7 days or acyclovir 400 mg five times a day for 7-10 days.

 

Note - Valacyclovir has superior bioavailability, superior efficacy, and lower side effects compared to acyclovir.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: There is no role for antibiotics in the treatment of Bell's palsy as it is not caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Option D. Physiotherapy: While physiotherapy, including facial exercises and eye protection measures, can be supportive, it is not the primary treatment and should be considered an adjunct to corticosteroid therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best initial management for a patient with Bell's palsy is corticosteroid therapy. Early administration within 72 hours of symptom onset greatly enhances the likelihood of complete recovery. Antivirals may be added in severe cases, but they are not the mainstay of treatment.

choices.text: Radiation exposure in CT scan is 20mSv
CT is the initial investigation for gallstones

questions.text: Identify the correct statement: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HU of water is zero

 

The Hounsfield Unit (HU) is a measure of radiodensity used in computed tomography (CT) scanning. By definition, the HU of water is zero, and this value serves as the reference point for measuring the density of other tissues. Values greater than zero indicate substances denser than water (e.g., bone, contrast material), while values less than zero indicate less dense substances (e.g., fat, air).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT uses non-filtered X-rays: This statement is incorrect. CT scans use filtered X-rays to remove low-energy X-rays that would not contribute to image formation but would increase patient radiation exposure.

 

Option B. Radiation exposure in CT scan is 20mSv: This is incorrect. Typical radiation doses for CT scans vary based on the body part being imaged. A head CT scan, for instance, typically involves a radiation dose of around 2 mSv, while an abdominal CT scan might be around 5 mSv. A dose of 20 mSv would be exceedingly high for a single CT scan.

 

Option C. CT is the initial investigation for gallstones: This is incorrect. Ultrasound is the initial investigation of choice for gallstones due to its high sensitivity, specificity, and lack of ionizing radiation. CT is more commonly used for other types of stones, such as kidney stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hounsfield Unit (HU) of water is zero, serving as a reference point for measuring the radiodensity of various tissues in CT imaging.

questions.text: Which of these hormones have intracellular receptors? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thyroxine

 

  • Thyroxine hormone act by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors.
  • All other hormones mentioned in the options bind to receptors on the cell membrane.
  • Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action.
  • The thyroid hormone receptors are either attached to the DNA genetic strands or located in proximity to them. The thyroid hormone receptor usually forms a heterodimer with retinoid X receptor (RXR) at specific thyroid hormone response elements on the DNA. On binding with thyroid hormone, the receptors become activated and initiate the transcription process.
  • Then large numbers of different types of messenger RNA are formed, followed within another few minutes or hours by RNA translation on the cytoplasmic ribosomes to form hundreds of new intracellular proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epinephrine: Epinephrine binds to adrenergic receptors on the cell membrane, which are G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Option C. Glucagon: Glucagon binds to glucagon receptors on the cell membrane, which are also G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Option D. Parathormone: Parathormone (PTH) binds to PTH receptors on the cell membrane, which are G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroxine acts by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors, initiating transcription and subsequent protein synthesis. This distinguishes it from hormones like epinephrine, glucagon, and parathormone, which bind to receptors on the cell membrane.

choices.text: Increase SBP and DBP at 6 weeks

questions.text: Physiological changes in pregnancy include all of the following except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in SBP and DBP at 6 weeks

 

During pregnancy, blood pressure decreases throughout pregnancy, with the maximum fall occurring in the second trimester. This is a normal physiological adaptation. An increase in blood pressure (either systolic or diastolic) is not a normal physiological change and could indicate a pathological condition like preeclampsia.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fasting Hypoglycemia and Postprandial Hyperglycemia: This is incorrect as this is a normal physiological change in pregnancy. Pregnant women experience fasting hypoglycemia and postprandial hyperglycemia as part of normal pregnancy adaptation.

 

Option C. Increase in RBC mass: This is incorrect as this is a normal physiological change. During pregnancy, there is an increase in RBC mass, although the increase in plasma volume is proportionally greater, leading to physiological anemia.

 

Option D. Peripheral Insulin Resistance: This is incorrect as this is a normal physiological change. Pregnancy is characterized by increased peripheral insulin resistance, which puts women at higher risk of developing gestational diabetes mellitus.

 

Educational Objective: 


Blood pressure normally decreases during pregnancy, with maximum fall in the second trimester. Any increase in blood pressure during pregnancy is abnormal and requires evaluation.

questions.text: All are causes for expanding blind spot, except? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoplasia of optic disc

 

Expansion of blind spot is not seen in optic disc hypoplasia. Optic nerve hypoplasia is the most common congenital optic disc anomaly that presents due to the underdevelopment of the optic nerve. The optic disc is surrounded by a yellowish pigmented ring known as a "double-ring" sign. This condition does not typically lead to changes in the size of the blind spot, as it primarily affects the development of the optic nerve rather than its function related to the blind spot's expansion.

 

 

  • Physiological blind spot is an area of absolute scotoma caused by the absence of photoreceptors in the region occupied by the optic disc.
  • Lesions affecting the optic disc region can expand the blind spot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. POAG: The rise in IOP in primary open-angle glaucoma causes pressure on the optic nerve head and consequent atrophy leading to expansion of the blindspot.

 

Option C. Papilledema: Papilledema is a passive disc swelling associated with raised intracranial pressure, and the edematous optic disc is swollen beyond its usual margins, causing the blind spot to enlarge.

 

Option D. Medullated nerve fibres: Medullated nerve fibers (optic disc medullation) is a condition of abnormal myelination of the nerve fibers of the retina, where myelination continues beyond lamina cribrosa and spreads into the retina beyond the optic disc. This leads to the expansion of the blind spot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic disc hypoplasia, a congenital underdevelopment of the optic nerve, does not typically result in an expanding blind spot, unlike conditions like POAG, papilledema, and the presence of medullated nerve fibers, which can directly affect the structure or function of the area surrounding the optic disc.

questions.text: A patient was admitted after a road traffic accident and later put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes to verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

 

His GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6.

 

Eye-opening to verbal command – 3

 

Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously – 6

 

In the case of endotracheal intubation, as given here, the verbal response score is noted as NT.

 

Total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable (NT).

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Weight loss+ Metformin + induction of ovulation with urinary gonadotrophins
Weight loss + folic acid, Try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation
Metformin + finasteride + Induction of ovulation
Weight loss+ Metformin + Induction of ovulation with clomiphene

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, experiencing 6 years of infertility, possesses a BMI of 33 and exhibits facial hair. Further investigations have diagnosed her with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and observed tubal spillage from both sides. Given her desire to conceive with her husband, what would be the most suitable management plan for her? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight loss + folic acid, try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation

 

Notably, even a modest weight loss (approximately 5% of body weight) can be beneficial for restoring ovulatory cycles in some obese PCOS patients. Therefore, spontaneous induction is attempted as the first option. Additionally, folic acid is routinely administered as a preventive measure before conception to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Weight loss + Metformin + induction of ovulation with urinary gonadotrophins: While weight loss and Metformin are both appropriate treatments for PCOS, initiating ovulation induction with urinary gonadotrophins might be premature. Typically, less invasive methods such as Clomiphene or Letrozole are tried before using gonadotrophins.

 

Option C. Metformin + finasteride + Induction of ovulation: This option includes Metformin, which is beneficial for insulin resistance in PCOS, and finasteride, which is used for hirsutism but not typically for fertility management. Finasteride is not used to induce ovulation. This plan overlooks the initial approach of weight loss and the potential for spontaneous ovulation.

 

Option D. Weight loss + Metformin + Induction of ovulation with clomiphene: This option is partially correct. While weight loss and Metformin are appropriate, the recommendation to immediately use Clomiphene for induction without trying for spontaneous ovulation is not aligned with the step-wise approach in fertility management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a woman with PCOS and infertility, the initial management should include weight loss and folic acid supplementation, with attempts at spontaneous ovulation before progressing to more invasive induction methods.

questions.text: Which pattern of inheritance does the pedigree chart denote? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autosomal-recessive disorder

 

The pedigree chart shown suggests an autosomal-recessive disorder based on several key observations:

 

  1. Horizontal Pattern: The affected individuals appear in the same generation but are not present in the preceding or subsequent generations. This pattern is characteristic of autosomal-recessive inheritance, where the disorder tends to skip generations unless both parents carry the recessive allele.
  2. Unaffected Parents: Both parents of affected individuals are unaffected, suggesting they are carriers of the recessive allele. In autosomal-recessive inheritance, an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to express the disorder.
  3. Carrier Frequency: According to autosomal-recessive inheritance patterns, when both parents are carriers, there is a 25% chance that their offspring will have the disorder (inherit two mutated genes), a 50% chance that the offspring will be carriers (inherit one mutated gene and one normal gene), and a 25% chance that the offspring will have a normal genotype (inherit two normal genes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal-dominant disorder: This pattern typically shows affected individuals in every generation, with both males and females equally likely to inherit the disorder. Affected individuals have a 50% chance of passing the disorder to their offspring, regardless of the other parent's genotype.

 

Option B. X-linked dominant disorder: This pattern would show affected females more frequently if the father is affected and can appear in every generation. However, affected males would pass the condition to all of their daughters and none of their sons.

 

Option D. X-linked recessive disorder: This pattern is more common in males, as they only have one X chromosome. Carrier females would pass the disorder to 50% of their sons, and 50% of their daughters would be carriers. However, in this pedigree, both males and females are affected equally, and the pattern does not suggest an X-linked inheritance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autosomal-recessive disorders are typically characterized by a horizontal pattern of inheritance, where the disorder appears in siblings of the same generation but may skip generations, with unaffected parents often being carriers.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of progressive enlargement of his hands and feet. On examination, he has frontal bossing, a large tongue, and spade-shaped hands. His shoe size has also increased over the past few years. Which of the following tests is most appropriate for diagnosing his condition? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1)

 

The patient’s presentation, including features such as frontal bossing, macroglossia (large tongue), and spade-shaped hands, strongly suggests acromegaly. Acromegaly results from excessive secretion of growth hormone (GH), typically due to a pituitary adenoma. Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) is the most reliable screening test for acromegaly because IGF-1 levels remain elevated throughout the day, unlike GH, which fluctuates. Elevated IGF-1 levels suggest acromegaly. A confirmatory test is the oral glucose tolerance test, where GH fails to suppress in acromegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid hormone assay: Thyroid function tests are used to diagnose thyroid disorders such as hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism. These tests are not used to diagnose acromegaly.

 

Option B. Serum prolactin: Although prolactinomas (prolactin-secreting tumors) are common pituitary adenomas, this patient's symptoms are not consistent with hyperprolactinemia. Prolactin measurement would not confirm acromegaly.

 

Option D. Serum testosterone: While testosterone testing may be indicated for evaluating hypogonadism, it is not relevant to the diagnosis of acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate initial test for diagnosing acromegaly is measuring insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) levels, as it reflects chronic exposure to elevated growth hormone.

questions.text: Which virus requires reverse transcriptase PCR for detection? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RSV

 

Explanation:

 

Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is an RNA virus that requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) to convert its RNA into DNA for detection. RT-PCR is a sensitive method used to detect and quantify RNA viruses by first converting their RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using the enzyme reverse transcriptase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses are DNA viruses and do not require reverse transcription. They can be detected using standard PCR methods that amplify their DNA directly.

 

Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): Epstein-Barr Virus is a DNA virus and uses standard PCR for detection. Reverse transcription is not necessary for DNA viruses.

 

Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Cytomegalovirus is also a DNA virus and can be detected through standard DNA PCR. Reverse transcription is not needed for its detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RSV, an RNA virus, requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) for detection by converting RNA into DNA.

questions.text: Deep y descent in Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) is seen in all of the following conditions except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac Tamponade

 

Deep y descent in JVP (Jugular venous pressure) is a characteristic finding in several conditions that affect the filling of the right ventricle. These conditions include constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and tricuspid regurgitation.

 

Cardiac tamponade, as it is associated with a blunted y descent in JVP rather than a deep y descent. In cardiac tamponade, the pericardial fluid accumulation restricts cardiac filling, leading to a decrease in the amplitude of the y descent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: This condition can cause a deep y descent due to the stiff ventricular walls allowing rapid passive filling only during early diastole.

 

Option C. Constrictive pericarditis: Similar to restrictive cardiomyopathy, constrictive pericarditis also shows a rapid early diastolic filling as the rigid pericardium constricts ventricular filling in late diastole, leading to a pronounced y descent.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: In tricuspid regurgitation, right atrial emptying occurs without the normal resistance posed by a competent tricuspid valve, often resulting in a prominent y descent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the presence of fluid in the pericardial space restricts all phases of cardiac filling, leading to a blunted or absent y descent, differentiating it from conditions where a deep y descent is observed.

questions.text:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. HIV  
  2. SLE  
  3. CLL  
  4. Hepatitis B
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPG) is seen in HIV, SLE, CLL, and Hepatitis B.

 

MPGN is caused due to immune-mediated injury. It often presents with a nephritic-nephrotic picture.

 

The causes of MPGN are as follows:

 

  • Primary MPGN (Idiopathic)
  • Secondary MPGN
  • System lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Alpha 1-antitrypsin deficiency
  • Infections - hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, schistosomiasis, endocarditis, infected ventriculoarterial shunts, chronic visceral abscesses
  • Malignancies - chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)

 

MPGN is characterized by the proliferation of cells predominantly in the mesangium and the capillary loops. Hence it is also called mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis.

 

There are 2 types of MPGN:

 

 

  • Duplication of the basement membrane gives a double contour or tram-track appearance. It is especially evident in silver or PAS stains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MPGN can be seen in various conditions, including HIV, SLE, CLL, and Hepatitis B, making it important to consider these diseases in the differential diagnosis of MPGN

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathological basis of disease 8th edition pg 1777

questions.text: After reaching an equilibrium state during exercising, it was found that the body was consuming oxygen at the rate of 1500 ml/min. Calculate the MET score if the baseline oxygen consumption at rest is 250 ml/min? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

MET (Metabolic Equivalent) is a unit used to estimate the energy expenditure of physical activities as a multiple of the resting metabolic rate (RMR). One MET is equal to the energy expended at rest, which is approximately 3.5 mL of oxygen per kilogram of body weight per minute (ml/kg/min).

 

To calculate the MET score for a given level of oxygen consumption, we need to first convert the oxygen consumption rate from ml/min to ml/kg/min, and then divide it by the resting oxygen consumption rate to get the MET value.

 

Assuming an average body weight of 70 kg, the oxygen consumption rate of 1500 ml/min corresponds to 21.4 ml/kg/min (1500 ml/min ÷ 70 kg).

 

Dividing this value by the resting oxygen consumption rate of 250 ml/min, we get:

 

MET score = 21.4 ml/kg/min ÷ 3.5 ml/kg/min ≈ 6

 

Therefore, the correct answer is B. 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The MET score represents the energy expenditure of an activity as a multiple of the resting metabolic rate.

choices.text: Sickle cell anemia

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is caused due to abnormal folding of proteins? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is caused due to abnormal folding of proteins.

 

CREUTZFELDT-JAKOB DISEASE (CJD)

 

  • Rare, degenerative, and fatal brain disorder.
  • Belongs to the group of transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs).
  • Results in the rapid deterioration of neurological function.

 

Causes

 

  • Abnormal prion proteins (misfolded) accumulate in the brain, leading to nerve cell damage.
  • Can be sporadic, genetic, or acquired through contaminated medical procedures

 

Symptoms

 

  • Rapidly progressive dementia.
  • Muscle stiffness, twitching, and weakness.
  • Behavioral changes, mood swings, and hallucinations.
  • Difficulty walking, speaking, and swallowing

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Based on clinical symptoms, medical history, and neurological examination.
  • Brain imaging and cerebrospinal fluid analysis to rule out other conditions.

 

Treatment

 

  • No cure or specific treatment available.
  • Supportive care to manage symptoms and maintain quality of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cirrhosis: Primarily caused by chronic liver injury due to alcohol abuse, hepatitis, or other liver diseases, and is not related to abnormal protein folding.

 

Option C. Nephritic syndrome: Characterized by inflammation of the glomeruli, leading to hematuria, hypertension, and proteinuria. The condition is generally caused by immune-mediated mechanisms, not by abnormal protein folding.

 

Option D. Sickle cell anemia: While it is caused by a protein mutation, it is not related to the abnormal folding of proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a disorder caused by the abnormal folding of prion proteins, leading to severe and fatal brain degeneration.

questions.text: As a public health expert, you are consulted about a series of outbreaks in a region that lacks significant prior vaccination campaigns. Given the imperative to contain the spread of disease and protect vulnerable populations, you are asked to prioritize a disease for which mass vaccination would provide the most immediate and impactful reduction in transmission. Which of the following diseases would most benefit from such an intervention? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Polio

 

  • Mass immunization is one of the best strategies to deal with outbreak of poliomyelitis.
  • Outbreak response immunization (ORI): Following the Acute flaccid paralysis case investigation and stool specimen collection, ORI is organized in community.
  • Children aged 0-59 months are given one dose of OPV regardless of previous immunization (in the village/locality of the AFP case)
  • Travel history of the child with AFP may suggest additional places of stay where ORI should also be conducted
  • Atleast 500 children are vaccinated

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Cholera: In case of a cholera outbreak, the most effective response would be chemoprophylaxis for a household or a closed community and. Drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis is Tetracycline.

 

Option B. Typhoid: control in case of an outbreak includes health education, water quality and sanitation improvement, prevent carriers from handling food, milk or water from others, and training of health professionals in diagnosis and treatment. Vaccination is not advised for typhoid outbreaks.

 

Option D. Tetanus: Tetanus is not a communicable disease in the traditional sense as it does not spread from person to person. Instead, it is caused by bacteria entering the body through wounds. Thus, mass vaccination for tetanus isn't typically utilized as an outbreak response but is important in routine immunization schedules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Polio, due to its potential for rapid spread and severe outcomes, along with the availability of an effective and easily administered vaccine, makes it the most critical focus for a mass vaccination campaign in response to an outbreak.
  • This strategy not only protects individuals but also aids in the global effort to eradicate polio.

 

Additional Information

 

Outbreak response for Measles includes

 

  1. Isolation for 7 days after the onset of rash
  2. Immunization of the contacts within 2 days of exposure (if vaccine is contraindicated, immunoglobulins should be given within 3-4 days of exposure)
  3. Prompt immunization at the beginning of an epidemic is essential to limit the spread.

choices.text: Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop
Prevents the cells from sticking to the slide surface

questions.text: What is the function of Acetone Free Methanol in Leishman stain? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop

Acetone-free methanol serves as a fixing agent in the Leishman stain process. Its primary function is to cause metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop, which preserves cellular architecture. This fixation occurs through protein denaturation and halts all biological processes, maintaining the cellular structure for microscopic examination. Therefore, the correct choice would be: "Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop."

 

The procedure of Leishman stain:

  • Freshly prepare and rapidly air-dry blood film.
  • Cover the film with Leishman's Stain (S018S) and allow it to act for 1 minute. Methanol in the stain fixes the preparation.
  • Add double the volume of distilled water to the slide and mix.
  • Allow the diluted stain to act for 10-12 minutes.
  • Wash the film with distilled water or phosphate buffer of pH 7.0, drain and dry in air and examine

 

Other Options:

Option B. Prevents the cells from sticking to the slide surface: This is incorrect because methanol doesn't prevent adhesion; rather, it preserves cellular structure through protein denaturation.

 

Option C. Colors the red cells: This is not the role of acetone-free methanol. The actual coloring of the cells is performed by the dye components in the Leishman stain (methylene blue and eosin).

 

Option D. Fixes cells to slide: While methanol is a fixative, its primary mechanism is stopping metabolic activity, not adhering cells to the slide. As previously noted, adhesion to the slide surface is the function of substances like albumin.
 

Educational Objective:


Acetone-free methanol in the Leishman stain primarily functions by causing metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop through protein denaturation, which preserves cellular architecture and enables proper staining and microscopic examination.

questions.text: An infant of 2 months had a serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. The mother might have taken which of the following drugs during the third trimester for this to occur?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Co-trimoxazole

 

Co-trimoxazole is a combination of two antibiotics: trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole. Sulfamethoxazole is a sulfonamide, which can displace bilirubin from its binding sites on plasma albumin. This displacement increases the free bilirubin levels in the blood, which can cross the blood-brain barrier and potentially lead to kernicterus, a type of brain damage resulting from very high levels of bilirubin in a newborn's blood.

 

When pregnant women take sulfonamides near term, these drugs can cross the placenta and affect the fetus, increasing the risk of hyperbilirubinemia and kernicterus in newborns. Therefore, Co-trimoxazole is contraindicated during the third trimester of pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ampicillin: Ampicillin is a penicillin antibiotic. It does not displace bilirubin from albumin, and therefore, it is not associated with an increased risk of hyperbilirubinemia or kernicterus in newborns.

 

Option C. Azithromycin: Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic. It is not known to displace bilirubin from albumin and is not associated with an increased risk of hyperbilirubinemia or kernicterus in newborns.

 

Option D. Chloramphenicol: Chloramphenicol is an antibiotic that can cause gray baby syndrome when given to newborns due to their immature liver enzymes, but it does not typically cause hyperbilirubinemia or kernicterus. It is not known to displace bilirubin from albumin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Co-trimoxazole, which contains the sulfonamide sulfamethoxazole, can displace bilirubin from plasma albumin, increasing the risk of hyperbilirubinemia and kernicterus in newborns. Therefore, it is contraindicated during the third trimester of pregnancy or during lactation.

questions.text: Sprengel’s deformity associated with all except: (INICET Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dextrocardia

 

SPRENGEL’S DEFORMITY

 

  • It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect.
  • The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position.

 

 

  • Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue.
  • From the superior angle of scapula a sheet or band-like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

  • It is associated with Klippel-Feil Syndrome/Scoliosis/Spina bifida (Diastematomyelia)/Cervical rib.
  • Clinical Feature: Shoulder and the scapula at a higher level than the opposite one, restriction of shoulder movement.
  • Treatment: There is no definitive treatment available. Surgery (Woodward procedure) is done for cosmetic reasons only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dextrocardia is rarely associated with Sprengel’s Deformity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with heartburn and increased salivation. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy result is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Barrett’s esophagus

 

This image indicates the diagnostic features of Barrett's esophagus. Note the transition between esophageal squamous mucosa and Barrett metaplasia, with abundant metaplastic goblet cells.

 

 

Barrett's esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa. It is a premalignant condition that confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

 

Hence, patients diagnosed with Barrett's Esophagus require that periodic endoscopy with biopsy, for detection of dysplasia every 1-2 years to detect dysplasias.

 

The presence of dysplasia is associated with prolonged symptoms, longer segment length, increased patient age, and Caucasian

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophagitis: While esophagitis, inflammation of the esophagus, may be seen in GERD, it does not show the characteristic intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells as seen in Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of cancer originates from the squamous cells of the esophagus and does not involve the metaplastic changes characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus can develop from Barrett's esophagus, but the histological image provided is more consistent with the premalignant stage of Barrett's esophagus rather than adenocarcinoma itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett's esophagus is a premalignant condition marked by intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells within the esophageal squamous mucosa, requiring regular surveillance for dysplasia and potential progression to adenocarcinoma.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1464

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presented with a hard painless testicular swelling. There were no inguinal, intra-abdominal or mediastinal lymph nodes on CT scan. The blood workup showed AFP levels of > 3000. USG shows uniform echotexture with small areas of necrosis. The next line of management is: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High inguinal orchidectomy  

 

This is the correct choice. In a young male presenting with a hard, painless testicular swelling and significantly elevated AFP levels (>3000), along with findings of uniform echotexture with small areas of necrosis on ultrasound (USG), there is a high suspicion of testicular cancer, particularly a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT). High inguinal orchidectomy is the standard initial surgical approach for the diagnosis and treatment of testicular cancer. The removed testicle is sent for pathological examination to confirm the diagnosis and determine the specific type of tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Core needle trucut biopsy: Core needle biopsy is contraindicate for testicular masses because it carries the risk of tumor spread or seeding along the biopsy tract.

 

Option C. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): FNAC is also not the preferred option for testicular masses due to the risk of tumor seeding and difficulties in obtaining an accurate diagnosis for testicular cancer.

 

Option D. Whole body PET/CT: Whole body PET/CT is typically used for staging and evaluating the extent of cancer after a diagnosis is confirmed. It is not the initial step in diagnosing a testicular mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given features that point towards the diagnosis of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) in stage I of the tumor. In a case of painless swelling of the testis, a testicular tumor should be suspected. The associated rise in AFP level points toward a diagnosis of NSGCT although tissue diagnosis is required to confirm the nature of the tumor. But tissue diagnosis is not a prerequisite for treatment, and hence, based on the available evidence a high inguinal orchidectomy is done in this case. Further treatment is followed up based on the findings of the excisional biopsy.

 

  • NSGCTs are not radiosensitive, but they are highly sensitive to combination chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cis-platinum (BEP chemotherapy). Up to 30% of NSGCT patients with stage I disease have subclinical metastases and will relapse if surveillance alone is done after orchidectomy.
  • Accordingly, some NSGCTs with good prognoses can be managed by surveillance protocols (using regular CT scanning and tumor marker measurement), with the more high-risk cases receiving chemotherapy.
  • For NSGCTs a 5-year survival rate of more than 90% is achievable in patients with good prognosis tumors, while for more advanced tumors, the 5-year survival rate is about 60%.

questions.text: Which of the following graphs represents normal response to OGTT? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Graph D

 

Explanation:

 

The normal response to an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is depicted by Graph D. During an OGTT, a patient ingests a specified amount of glucose (commonly 75 grams), and blood glucose levels are measured at intervals to evaluate how well the body handles glucose. In a normal response:

 

  • Blood glucose levels rise to a peak within 1 hour after ingestion.
  • Glucose levels then decline and return to baseline by 2 hours.
  • The glucose levels do not exceed the renal threshold at any point during the test.

 

This pattern reflects the body's effective regulation of blood glucose levels and the normal function of insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Graph A: Graph A might depict an abnormal glucose tolerance curve, such as one seen in impaired glucose tolerance or gestational diabetes, where glucose levels remain elevated for a prolonged period or fail to return to baseline.

 

Option B. Graph B: Graph B could show a response with an abnormal peak or delayed return to baseline, indicative of glucose intolerance or a diagnostic criterion for diabetes mellitus.

 

Option C. Graph C: Graph C might represent an exaggerated glucose peak or prolonged elevated glucose levels, suggesting a pathological glucose tolerance response consistent with diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A normal OGTT response features a peak in blood glucose levels within 1 hour, followed by a return to baseline levels within 2 hours, without exceeding the renal threshold.

 

Ref: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/301045468_VARIANTS_OF_ORAL_GLUCOSE_TOLERANCE_TEST_OGTT_CURVE_IN_GESTATIONAL_DIABETES_MELLITUS_GDM

questions.text: All of the following are the components of Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme except: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 6 health functionaries

 

  • Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) or Intensified Iron Plus Initiative launched in 2018 uses a strategic framework called the 6x6x6 strategy. 
  • This includes 6 beneficiaries, 6 interventions, and 6 institutional mechanisms. 
  • The program does not include "6 health functionaries" as a component.

 

The 6x6x6 strategy includes:

 

1. 6 beneficiaries:

 

  • Children aged 6-59 months
  • Children aged 5-9 years
  • Adolescents aged 10-19 years
  • Women of reproductive age (20-49 years, non-pregnant, non-lactating)
  • Pregnant women
  • Lactating women

 

2. 6 interventions:

 

  • Iron and folic acid supplementation
  • Deworming (biannually with albendazole)
  • Behavior change communication
  • Iron fortified foods
  • Testing and treatment of anemia
  • Increasing awareness about non-nutritional causes of anemia

 

3. 6 institutional mechanisms for program implementation and monitoring

 

  • The main aim of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program is to reduce the prevalence of anemia by 3 percentage points per year among children, adolescents, and women in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) between 2018-2022.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Anemia Mukt Bharat program follows a 6x6x6 strategy which includes 6 beneficiaries, 6 interventions, and 6 institutional mechanisms, but does not include 6 health functionaries.

 

 

IFA TABLETS [Anemia Mukt Bharat]

questions.text: Which is the first-order neuron in the optic pathway? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rods and cones

 

  • The rods and cones act as the first-order neurons They give the signals to the bipolar cells act as second order neurons in the optic pathway. They serve as an intermediate link between the photoreceptor cells and the ganglion cells (option B), which are the third-order neurons.
  • The electrical signals from the bipolar cells are further transmitted to the ganglion cells. The axons of ganglion cells form the optic nerve, which carries visual information from the retina to the visual processing centers in the brain.
  • The optic nerve fibers project to different regions of the brain, including the lateral geniculate body (option C), which is part of the thalamus and is involved in visual processing. Therefore, the correct correct answer is A.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ganglion cells: Incorrect. Ganglion cells are the third-order neurons in the optic pathway.

 

Option C. Cells in lateral geniculate body: Incorrect. These cells are involved in the later stages of visual processing and are not first-order neurons.

 

Option D. Bipolar cells: Incorrect. Bipolar cells are the second-order neurons in the optic pathway.

 

Educational Objective

 

In the optic pathway, the first-order neurons are the photoreceptor cells, specifically rods and cones, which convert light into electrical signals. These signals are then relayed through bipolar cells to ganglion cells, whose axons form the optic nerve, ultimately transmitting visual information to the brain.

questions.text: A patient displaying lytic lesions on the skull is being considered for a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. What represents a distinctive discovery on electron microscopy among the following options? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Birbeck granules

 

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histiocytes: While Langerhans cells are a type of histiocyte, the presence of histiocytes alone is not specific to LCH. The defining feature is the presence of Birbeck granules.

 

Option C. Eosinophils: Eosinophils are often present in LCH lesions, especially in eosinophilic granuloma, but they are not a distinctive finding on electron microscopy.

 

Option D. Giant cells: Giant cells may be present in a variety of inflammatory or granulomatous conditions, but they are not specific to LCH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is a distinctive and pathognomonic finding in Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

questions.text: A rape victim is brought to the casualty of a government hospital for examination. Within what time should a vaginal swab be taken to look for the presence of spermatozoa? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Within 72 hours

 

Spermatozoa can be demonstrated only if a vaginal swab is taken within 72 hours of an assault.

 

Semen can be demonstrated on evidence on the outside of the body and on materials such as clothing upto 96 hours.

 

Educational Objective

 

Presence of spermatozoa and other microorganisms

 

•Spermatozoa remain motile in the vagina for 6-8 hours, occasionally up to 12 hours.

•Nonmotile forms can be detected for about 24 hours, rarely up to 48-72 hours.

•Detection involves aspirating vaginal contents and examining under a microscope.

•Motile sperms suggest recent intercourse; nonmotile sperms indicate a broader time frame (12-72 hours).

•Intact spermatozoa are rarely found in the vagina after 72 hours.

•Seminal fluid detection from vasectomized males requires prostatic acid phosphatase demonstration.

•P30, a semen-specific glycoprotein, is used as a screening test, detectable in vaginal fluid for about 27 hours.

choices.text: Treatment of migraine
Treatment of Lennox Gastaut syndrome
Prophylaxis of ADHD
Treatment of dementia

questions.text: Topiramate is used for? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Treatment of Lennox Gastaut syndrome

 

Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that can be used for the treatment of Lennaux-Gestaut Syndrome (characterized by multifocal seizures, having <2.5 Hz spike and wave pattern in EEG). It primarily works by blocking the Na+ channels, and to some extent it also enhances the GABA receptor currents and limiting the activation of the AMPA-kainate subtype of glutamate receptors.

 

Topiramate can also be used for:

 

  • C: Decreasing the Craving of alcohol
  • O: Obesity
  • M: Migraine Prophylaxis (not treatment)
  • B: Bipolar disorder.

 

So, among the given options, best answer is Lennox Gastaut syndrome. Do not get confused with migraine as the options specifically mentions the treatment of migraine whereas topiramate is used for prophylaxis of migraine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment of migraine: Topiramate is used for the prophylaxis of migraines, not for the acute treatment of migraine attacks.

 

Option C. Prophylaxis of ADHD: Topiramate is not indicated for the prophylaxis or treatment of ADHD.

 

Option D. Treatment of dementia: Topiramate is not used for the treatment of dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topiramate is primarily used for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy in children. It is also used for the prophylaxis of migraines, reducing alcohol cravings, aiding in weight loss, and as an adjunct therapy for bipolar disorder.

choices.text: Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up

questions.text: A 63-year-old female patient presented with a 5x1 cm lump in the left upper outer quadrant, with no axillary lymph node involvement. Mammography revealed BIRADS 4b staging. She underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final HE reports showed high nuclear grade DCIS with 7 mm margin clearance. What is the further management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

After breast-conserving surgery (BCS) for ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), adjuvant radiotherapy is typically recommended. Radiotherapy has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of local recurrence after BCS for DCIS. In this patient, despite having a 7 mm margin clearance, the presence of high nuclear grade DCIS warrants the use of adjuvant radiotherapy to minimize the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adjuvant chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is primarily used for invasive breast cancers, especially when there is a high risk of systemic spread. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and hence systemic chemotherapy is not typically indicated.

 

Option C. Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up: Regular follow-up is crucial for any patient who has undergone treatment for breast cancer, but it is not the primary management strategy immediately after surgery for high nuclear grade DCIS.

 

Option D. Trastuzumab therapy: Trastuzumab is a targeted therapy used for HER2-positive invasive breast cancers. DCIS that is HER2-positive does not typically receive trastuzumab therapy, as the benefits of such treatment in non-invasive cancer have not been clearly established.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on the Van Nuys prognostic index, the patient’s score is: High grade- 3 points, Margins 7 mm-2 points, Size 5 cm- 3 points and age 63 years- 1 point= 9 points.

 

The recommended next step in the patient's management would be adjuvant radiotherapy for scores 7 to 9.

 

 

Score: 4 to 6: wide excision alone

 

7 to 9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

10 to 12: Mastectomy

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal distension and intermittent fever. Peripheral smear findings are normal. A tumor is resected and the histopathology image of the resected lymph node is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Castleman disease

 

The given clinical scenario and histopathological image showing follicular hyperplasia of lymph nodes are suggestive of Castleman disease.

 

Castleman disease (angiofollicular lymph node hyperplasia. is a lymphoproliferative disorder that can be associated with HHV-8 (multicentric Castleman disease or MCD. or idiopathic (unicentric Castleman disease or UCD).

 

4 subtypes –

 

  1. Unicentric CD (UCD. involves a single enlarged lymph node or multiple enlarged lymph nodes within a single lymph node region that demonstrate CD-like features under the microscope.
  2. Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)–associated multicentric Castleman disease (HHV-8–associated MCD. involves multiple regions of enlarged lymph nodes.
  3. POEMS-associated, HHV-8–negative MCD: POEMS (polyradiculoneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, monoclonal plasma cell proliferative disorder, and skin changes) syndrome that co-occurs with HHV-8–negative MCD
  4. HHV-8–negative/idiopathic multicentric Castleman disease (iMCD. involves multiple regions of enlarged lymph nodes with CD-like features, flulike illness, abnormal blood counts, and dysfunction of vital organs (see Presentation) due to an unknown cause

 

There are 3 major histological subtypes:

 

  • Hypervascular (UCD) -
  • Lollipop appearance - atrophic germinal centers with radially penetrating blood vessels
  • Onion skin appearance of mantle zone around germinal centers

  • Plasma cell subtype (UCD or MCD - hypertrophic germinal centers, increased vascularity
  • Mixed variant (MCD. - mix of hypervascular and plasma cell subtype features in the same lymph node

 

The clinical features include:

 

  • Multiple enlarged lymph nodes
  • Night sweats
  • Weight loss
  • Weakness and fatigue
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

 

As this condition is associated with elevated levels of IL-6, the treatment involves IL-6 inhibitors like siltuximab and tocilizumab.

 

  1. Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) is a type of herpesvirus that is associated with several diseases, including:
  2. Kaposi's sarcoma (KS): HHV8 is the primary cause of KS, a type of cancer that causes the growth of abnormal blood vessels in the skin, mucous membranes, and other organs.
  3. Primary effusion lymphoma (PEL): HHV8 is also associated with PEL, a rare type of cancer that affects immune cells.
  4. Multicentric Castleman disease (MCD): HHV8 is implicated in the development of MCD, a rare disorder of the lymph nodes and related tissues that can cause fever, fatigue, and other symptoms.
  5. HIV-associated lymphomas: HHV8 is a co-factor in the development of some types of lymphomas, particularly those that are associated with HIV infection. E.g.: Plasmablastic lymphoma.

 

It is important to note that not all individuals infected with HHV8 will develop these diseases, and other factors, such as genetic susceptibility and immune status, may also play a role in disease development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Castleman disease is a lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by follicular hyperplasia and is associated with HHV-8 in some cases. The treatment involves IL-6 inhibitors due to the elevated IL-6 levels.

questions.text: Out of the options given below the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET) is: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

Most common type of PNET seen is: Insulinoma

 

Insulinomas are the most common type of PNETs. They produce excess insulin, leading to hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) in affected individuals. Insulinomas are typically benign and occur more frequently than other types of PNETs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma: Gastrinoma is a type of PNET that produces excess gastrin hormone. It is associated with a condition called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Gastrinomas are relatively less common than insulinomas.

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma: Somatostatinomas are rare PNETs that produce excess somatostatin hormone. They can occur in the pancreas or other parts of the digestive system. They are less common than insulinomas.

 

Option D. VIPoma: VIPomas, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome or pancreatic cholera, are PNETs that produce vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). These tumors are relatively rare compared to insulinomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PNETs are a rare type of pancreatic tumor that originate from neuroendocrine cells in the pancreas.
  • PNETs are classified as either functioning or non-functioning based on their ability to produce hormones.
  • Diagnosis of PNETs typically involves imaging studies such as CT or MRI, as well as biopsy or blood tests to measure hormone levels.
  • Treatment options for PNETs may include surgery, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy, depending on the size, location, and type of tumor.

 

Insulinoma:

 

  • The investigation of choice for insulinoma 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels.
  • Medical management:
    • Octreotide
  • Surgical management - Enucleation

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used for diagnosing abdominal pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Studdiford criteria

 

  • Studdiford Criteria is for diagnosis of Primary abdominal pregnancy
    • Both tubes and ovaries normal with no marks of injury
    • Utero-peritoneal fistula should not be seen
    • The placenta should be attached exclusively to the peritoneal surface

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spiegelberg Criteria: Spiegelberg Criteria is for Ovarian ectopic

 

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • The gestation sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • The gestation sac in the ovary must be connected to the uterus by the ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall on histopathology

 

Option B. Rubin criteria: Rubin criteria is for Cervical pregnancy

 

Option D. Ring of fire: Ring of fire is a sign seen on USG-Color doppler in an unruptured tubal ectopic

 

Educational Objective:

 

Studdiford Criteria are used to diagnose primary abdominal pregnancy. This criterion involves:

 

  1. Ensuring that both fallopian tubes and ovaries are normal with no signs of injury.
  2. Confirming that no utero-peritoneal fistula is present.
  3. Verifying that the placenta is attached exclusively to the peritoneal surface.

 

These criteria help distinguish primary abdominal pregnancy from other types of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Ref: Page no 219, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text:
In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. Before examining the patient
  2. After examining the patient
  3. After touching the patient's surroundings
  4. Hands are visibly soiled
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B and C only

 

Healthcare personnel should perform hand hygiene with soap and water when hands are visibly soiled.

 

Healthcare personnel should use an alcohol-based hand rub for the following clinical indications:

 

  • Immediately before touching a patient
  • Before performing an aseptic task (e.g., placing an indwelling device) or handling invasive medical devices
  • Before moving from work on a soiled body site to a clean body site on the same patient
  • After touching a patient or the patient’s immediate environment
  • After contact with blood, body fluids, or contaminated surfaces
  • Immediately after glove removal

 

Other Option:

 

D. Hands are visibly soiled: In this case, hand washing with soap and water is recommended rather than using a sanitizer.

 

Educational Objective:
